body: > Sometimes we know where most energy will be and discard coefficients as a post-processing step. If they happen to be high-freq coeffs, however, they eat up majority of compute - and it'd be much more effective to not compute them at all. This shouldn't be hard to implement - worst part will be adjusting meta & tests. Yes, i completely agree. This is what i did in `scattering.m` with `gamma_bounds`. Intuitively, we want to shrink the area of the rectangle below, by adjusting the `xi1min`, `xi1max`, `xi2min`, `xi2max` bound below: Bonus points if this can be done without having to re-define the `Scattering1D` object from scratch. > 2.Decimating grants speed & memory without changing the scale of invarianc Yes. But decimated relative to _what_? There's nothing in this that we couldn't do with an appropriate API for `stride` and `bins_per_octave` `stride = Td *T/2` and `bins_per_octave = Q/Fd` TL;DR this is important but we should be careful to express it in a unit that is intuitive. I don't want 2 more kwargs that default to `None`

> Yes. But decimated relative to what?

Decimated right after lowpassing. Else, I don't get the question

> bins_per_octave = Q/Fd

This isn't same: `compute(downsampled) != downsample(computed)`.

> stride = Td *T/2

Dunno what the 2's about but 1) changing `T` changes scale of invariance; 2) simply increasing stride is akin to excess subsampling, which isn't equivalent to decimating

> I don't want 2 more kwargs that default to None

They can't be done as post-processing steps, and can improve speed & memory at least two-fold. If we're getting overwhelmed by kwargs, we could define an optional `cfg` dictionary arg that stores all the "advanced" configs - less namespace clutter, more unlimited features.
But then you change the scale of invariance, since `scipy.signal.decimate` applies an anti-aliasing filter, i.e. a low-pass filter.
Yes, but it's a different low-pass, with much less blur, as shown by the GIF. It more faithfully captures the original.

I see. Then it's more a problem of `phi` design.
Right now we have `phi`= Gaussian, which makes energy conservation ~easy~ _easier_ but may not be the only reasonable choice.
By default, `decimate` uses an order 8 Chebyshev type I filter instead. That's only one of many possible choices.

I guess it's a tradeoff between aliasing and blurring?

If the profile of `phi` truly makes a different in classification (there is some evidence it does, see LEAF by Zeghidour et al.) then i imagine that the best option is to set `T` to a low value and then learn a non-Gaussian average pooling operator on top.

> Then it's more a problem of phi design.

No. The primary role of the Gaussian is to impose invariance; downsampling is a bonus. The decimating lowpass isn't suited for invariance. One _can_ change `T` purely for sake of downsampling, but shouldn't: the two steps should be separate.

> then i imagine that the best option is to set T to a low value and then learn

That's a choice the user can always make. This doesn't solve the case when we need a specific `T` but can't afford it per speed or memory, however.

To emphasize, the purpose is to enable superior downsampling _purely for sake of downsampling_, while minimally affecting the scale of invariance. This is especially important in JTFS, as we often really don't want a higher `F` invariance, but do want a higher `F` downsampling, and can afford generous amounts of it with minimal loss of information.

OK, then i'm completely lost. What are we trying to do?

> This is especially important in JTFS, as we often really don't want a higher F invariance, but do want a higher F downsampling, and can afford generous amounts of it with minimal loss of information.

Sounds like we should just downsample more by default then?

Are you saying you want `stride > T` ?

> Sounds like we should just downsample more by default then?

Maybe, but I'd best leave it to the user

> Are you saying you want stride > T ?

Exactly

issue.title: `j2 > j1` needs rework

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: The motivation is to convolve with coefficients from previous orders of supports to the _right_ of the wavelet doing the convolving, per scattering energy theorems. This motivation is ill-achieved when conditioned on `j`: Note the left-most blue `psi2` is almost entirely outside the support of blue `psi1`s, yet it's omitted from second order scattering because its support doesn't fully decay into the `j=0` octave. That's a potentially heavy loss of information. `scattering.m`'s approach via `xi2 > xi1` is better, but perhaps suboptimal if the goal's to avoid significant support intersection. The ideal approach is to condition directly upon the criterion itself - which is doable via the `'support'` meta: ``` if ((psi2['xi'] + psi2['support']//2) < (psi1['xi'] + psi1['support']//2)): ``` This is particularly important if `J2 < J1`, where highest `j2` never reaches `J1` and potentially omits majority of `U1` from second order.

issue.title: JTFS mess

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Long story short, I made a significant mistake in implementation that affects all configurations. Namely, unpadding and striding along frequency, in freq scattering. My bad.

Good news is, only `aligned=False` and `'recalibrate'` are severely affected. `aligned=True` and `'resample'` may oversample for non-smallest `N_frs`, and `out_3D=False` may unpad incorrectly. It's possible, and likely, that `True` and `'resample'` work entirely correctly for a given config, just not guaranteed. Implications are "excess data" and "some info lost", and latter should be negligible in most cases.

I will fix it, hopefully soon. I'll open it as a PR to #781, write a summary of changes to guide reviewers, and take any questions. For now, `'resample'` and `aligned=True` should work well enough.

@lostanlen @rastegah @lylyhan @changhongw

issue.title: Bad default: `average_fr=False` & `aligned=True`

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
All second-order coefficients, except spinned `j1_fr=0`, are oversampled, which drastically amplifies output size and overfitting. Arguably the worst configuration of all. We should either default to both `True` or both `False`.

Since there's still some confusion, another attempt at explaining: `aligned=True` is an oversampled `aligned=False`. Filterbank parameters are independent of `aligned`, so in this sense the "paths" are unaffected.

 - 1D convs: all configs are valid. We pack `n2, n1_fr, n1` along channels, where they "don't talk" (every learned convolution filter sees only one path)
 - 2D convs: all `out_3D=True` configs are valid
 - 3D convs: all `out_3D=True` configs are valid if `n2` is packed along channels (so convolve over `(n1_fr, n1, t)` with spins split), since `out_3D=True` always enforces `aligned=True` on per-`n2` basis
 - 4D convs: no configs are valid. Only here is `aligned=False` a dealbreaker.
 - "all configs" assumes `'resample'`, since `'recalibrate'` breaks actual path alignment.

#791 makes `average_fr=True` a close equivalent to `average_fr=False` on averting loss of information due to averaging up to a certain `F`, but that's for later.

@lostanlen @janden

body: Scattering iterators #735 will solve everything inshahallah
